newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Midwest direct hogs up $0.50-$1.00 - dealers.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Midwest direct hogs up $0.50-$1.00 - dealers.

text.p: U.S. Midwest direct cash hogs early Wednesday sold $0.50 to $1.00 per cwt higher, supported by light hog movement and strong packer demand for those hogs that are marketed, livestock dealers said.
Interior Iowa and southern Minnesota hogs sold $0.50 higher at $55.00 to $56.00 in the country and $56.50 to $57.50 at plants, they said.

Illinois hogs sold $0.50 to $1.00 higher at $55.50 to $56.00 in the country and $56.50 to $57.00 at plants, although some plants reportedly paid premiums for top quality hogs of $2.00 to $2.50 over USDA's posted high Tuesday of $56.00.

Indiana hogs sold $0.50 to $1.00 higher at $55.50 to $56.00 in the country and $57.00 to $57.50 at plants, dealers said. Marketings in central Indiana were brisk, but moderate in the rest of the state, several dealers said.

Ohio hogs sold $0.50 higher at $53.00 to $54.00 in the country and $55.00 to $56.00 at plants. Farmers were still having trouble getting into saturated fields following heavy rainfall earlier this week.
Live hog strength also was attributed higher pork prices, with estimated gross cutout values Tuesday quoted up $0.52 to $0.60 per cwt, USDA reported.
